body: Sorry for late response and also got disappeared for last few months, this definitely sounds like a good idea, I'm not sure if this supported in `go sdk` yet. I'll dig more into this and update with details.

issue.title: Access using AAD

repository.name: azure-storage-blob-go
repository.description: Microsoft Azure Blob Storage Library for Go

issue.body:
### Which version of the SDK was used?
Current version 0.6.0

### Which platform are you using? (ex: Windows, Linux, Debian)
Linux

This is more of a question than an issue, I see that there is a way to authenticate azure storage with AAD in this [.Net example](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-auth-aad-msi). I couldn't find any examples in `go code` to support something like this. Is this supported. Can you please confirm if this is supported? 

We have an active issue [rclone#3213](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/3213), AAD authentication feature with storage would help unblocking this.

body: Based on initial investigation, it doesn't look like supported to me in current SDK. I've opened up an issue with client SDK team, will update more details when we hear from them.
I was wondering if this actually got done?

The current SDK supports OAuth but doesn't actually get the token. On the gripping hand, azcopy does support MSI authentication and is MIT-licensed, so the [relevant bits](https://github.com/Azure/azure-storage-azcopy/blob/master/common/oauthTokenManager.go) can be lovingly copied into rclone.
@backerman is this something you want to have a go at?

@ncw I need to add tests and support for user-assigned identities, but I've got an [initial implementation](https://github.com/backerman/rclone/tree/personal/backerman/msi) in my fork that works with the system-assigned identity.

It's currently using a dedicated boolean to enable this option, but defaulting to a system-assigned identity if there are no explicit credentials added could also work.

@backerman I had a look at your fork and I think you are doing very well :-)

I suggest you write lots of help under the `use_msi` definition as that is what gets built into the docs. The first line is the config flag parameter `--azureblob-use-msi` help string.

> It's currently using a dedicated boolean to enable this option, but defaulting to a system-assigned identity if there are no explicit credentials added could also work.

I think this is very similar to the [`env_auth` flag in s3](https://rclone.org/s3/#authentication) so there would be precedence for it needing to be enabled. The S3 backend default to anonymous access if no credentials are supplied.

What would most Azure users expect?
The same behavior as S3 should be fine.

issue.title: azureblob: add managed identity support

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Adds a configuration option (`azureblob_use_msi`) to use a managed service identity when authenticating to Azure from an Azure virtual machine, which eliminates the need to manage explicit credentials. This method acquires a bearer token (valid for 24 hours) from the [Azure Instance Metadata Service](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/managed-identities-azure-resources/how-to-use-vm-token#get-a-token-using-http), and if a temporary error is returned will retry using the exponential backoff method specified in the linked documentation.

The token is not presently persisted to disk; if users are expected to invoke the `rclone` binary a large number of times in a short period that functionality would be desirable. The present implementation also does not check token validity before calling the Azure Storage blob API, so if a `rclone` invocation lasts long enough that it calls the API more than 24 hours after process start that call will fail.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Issue #3213.

#### Checklist

- [X] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request).
- [X] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [X] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [X] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [X] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)
